textDescription: Effectiveness monitoring on the 8 fisher WHAs in the South Peace region last occured 8 years ago with cameras on existing and previously used den trees. While some activity was detected at den tree, the nature of the maternal den clusters means that cameras will likely miss fisher denning in the area and a more widespread sampling effort is needed to evaluate whether WHAs are currently being used. Hair snagging and DNA analysis is proposed for th

selectProjectName.label: Fisher WHA Effectiveness Monitoring and Development NE region
selectProjectName.value: Fisher WHA Effectiveness Monitoring and Development NE region

General-FinalNotes: I received ED(James Cuell) approval on July 24, 2025.  I have put the full amount in that was originally requested, but realistically, the late fiscal funding potential amount of $14,000 for the design and field verification of fisher WHAs in the area impacted by Site C (where fisher were tagged for the EIA and all the data exists) is the more realistic project at this time.
Status-StatusNotes: The original ask was for two parts; 1) Fisher WHA effectiveness monitoring and 2) Fisher WHA polygon development in the area impacted by the Site C project.  Depending on the date of decision, if approved, the full project (both parts) may not be possible to complete.  For part 1, there is pre-assembly of hair snags, field team organization (which will require the support of a contractor) required and the latest date to commence field work would be the last week of January.  Part 2 is easily achievable at a later date, but would need to be started by March 1, 2026 in order to complete before fiscal year end.  Part 2 requires desktop support and field visits (again with contractor support).  I have broke out the funding for part 2 in the "late fiscal funding potential" section below.

editGrid.notesOnThisStob: I anticipate this money would be all contracted out at this late stage.

CorrectProjectDescription:
This description is cut off.  It is missing some information. Funding will support two actions: 1) we will review existing fisher and habitat data in the area of the Site C project and propose and ground truth new fisher WHAs; 2) monitor the 8 existing fisher WHAs in the South Peace region for effectiveness.
Note:  BC Hydro has fallen short on mitigating for fisher and given the regulators are aware of this short fall, could we be considered responsible for also not doing anything when some potential options, such as fisher WHAs, are available for action?  The new proposed fisher WHAs would be in proximity to the Site C project and would use the data collected on tagged fishers from the Site C EIA.  BC Hydro supports the idea but has indicated they don't have the resources to conduct the work to build WHA proposals.

Status-StatusNotes:
The project has multiple components: installation of water monitoring stations, hydrograph rating curve development, field habitat surveys and drone habitat surveys. Water monitoring stations have been installed on each creek and main tributaries (Arrow/Okell Creek and Big Sand/Little Sand Creek) with multiple rating curve measurements taken over the summer. Field habitat surveys (including a drone habitat survey contract) were scheduled to coincide with low-water in September and were impacted by strike action and were not completed. 

Outstanding actions include the maintenance of water monitoring stations over winter and into spring 2026, with continued collection of rating curve measurements (plus associated travel and material expenses). However, since habitat surveys represented the majority of planned spending for this project, the remaining project funding (~$28k) will be returned and reapplied for during the 2026/27 fiscal period.
CorrectProjectDescription:
Development of Environmental Flow Needs (EFNs) for two streams in the Kootenays to support water use/allocation decisions, particularly for potential fishing regulation changes as well as drought management. Focus will be on streams susceptible to low flow/temperature impacts, high fisheries value and those that support current water diversion licences. 

$40k was allocated for this project through the LBIS-Water Quality stream with the intention to install water monitoring stations on two streams in the Kootenays (Arrow Creek, Creston and Sand Creek, Jaffray) and conduct habitat assessments to inform EFN establishment using new provincial protocols in development.

Status-StatusNotes: The initial 13k has been through EMC and is fully encumbered in contracts or through direct invoices. For the remaining 20 k, internal staff have initiated planning with project partners to identify priority trees for scion collection this season based on confirmed breeding values and which trees have had collections in recent years and identifying with partners where additional funds for seed stratification or gaps in planning for future planting.

editGrid.notesOnThisStob: The 13k was already approved and through EMC prior to the re-org and will stay with Christine Petrovicic, but additional funding will be under South Area under Kenric Walburger

CorrectProjectDescription:
Whitebark pine (Pinus albicaulis) is federally listed as Endangered under the Species at Risk Act (SARA), with draft critical habitat identified in British Columbia. It is a keystone species in high-elevation ecosystems, stabilizing soils, regulating snowmelt, and providing critical high-calorie food for wildlife such as grizzly bears and Clark’s nutcrackers.
The draft Federal Recovery Strategy identifies two essential actions for the species’ recovery: to increase the frequency of trees that have elevated resistance to white pine blister rust and to conserve genetic diversity represented among and within populations that may be lost by rapid population decline and/or increasing isolation of stands.
This project directly supports the conservation of genetic diversity through scion collection of confirmed rust resistant parent trees, seed extraction and stratification for future planting and further assessment of future planting areas.

editGrid.notesOnThisStob: The existing contracts will stay under the coding listed above. Additional approved funding will likely be under South Area - Kenric Walburger

CorrectProjectDescription:
Williamson’s Sapsucker (Sphyrapicus thyroideus) is federally listed as Endangered under the Species at Risk Act (SARA), has Critical Habitat identified in British Columbia, and overlaps with numerous other species at risk and wildlife habitat. Its survival is primarily threatened by the loss or degradation of breeding habitat through the removal of mature forest. The federal recovery strategy aims to ensure the persistence of the populations in Canada by maintaining them at or above their current abundance and distribution.

South Area work has focused on updates to the 2014 Best Management Practices for Forestry and updating range wide habitat suitability modeling to support various recovery actions in coordination with regions. The current BMPs, last updated in 2014, are outdated and require revisions to remain effective in supporting habitat management and recovery actions for this endangered species. BMP updates have been drafted over the past two years by a combination of external and internal expertise. Federal and provincial recovery strategies list implementation of BMPs as an urgent action to support population recovery. 

Contracts to date have supported: 
•	Final habitat suitability mapping,
•	A finalized science-based companion document, and
•	Finalized rapid field assessment protocols.

Additional work would support:
•	Combine silviculture expertise and provincial species expert advice to identify remaining operational forestry issues with the BMP Updates ahead of review and comment phase. 
•	Create a written plan for addressing gaps in habitat suitability modeling in the East Kootenay population and remaining field verification required to finalize mapping. This work would also updating any associated field protocols that would be used in the spring of 2026 and for any future habitat suitability mapping updates across the species range. 

This work will support the final updates to the BMPs and will ensure a comprehensive package for forest licensee and First Nation engagement and will ensure the BMPs can be effectively implemented in a variety of forest management contexts, while continuing to support recovery objectives for Williamson’s Sapsucker. 
Implementation aligns with the current ministry’s service plan Goals 1 and 2; objective 1.1 and 2.1. Concurrently, this work aligns with the Tripartite Framework on Nature Conservation objectives 6.4.1, 8.1, 8.4.2. 

This work cannot wait, as primary forest management activities are actively occurring across Williamson’s Sapsucker’s range, contributing to ongoing loss and degradation of Critical Habitat. Effectiveness monitoring has shown that uptake of the current Best Management Practices (BMPs) is low—only about 33%—and the proposed updates directly address identified gaps and incorporate key learnings that are expected to significantly improve adoption by forest licensees.
Finalizing these updates is critical to ensure that licensees have timely access to accurate, science-based guidance, including updated habitat mapping and assessment protocols. Without these revisions, current forestry practices risk undermining conservation efforts and delaying progress toward meeting recovery goals outlined in the federal and provincial recovery strategies.
CorrectT4WAction:
While this is a species at risk, this project supports Action 7 for this species includes ensuring all Williamson's sapsucker data are updated in the Wildlife Species Inventory including a separate entry in the BC Data Catalogue for Williamson's sapsucker that includes all habitat models, and all inventory data including all known nest trees for this species.
Also, supports action 9 as it supports on the ground stewardship actions.

General-FinalNotes: Prior to the re-org, I had 35k allocated for this project under Christine Petrovcic's ENL allocation and she has indicated post re-org that she would still support my use of these funds. I am uncertain if coding for this would remain under Christine or transfer to Kenric Walburger if this is approved.
Status-StatusNotes: Internal staff have reviewed previous coastal work, prepared a project background, goals and scope of work for this project. The project rationale is prepared for the EMC process if funds are approved.
CorrectProjectDescription:
Few Western Screech Owl surveys have been conducted in the B.C. interior since 2012-2014, and no standardized long-term monitoring program exists to track populations or range-wide changes (COSEWIC 2012).  

Recovery goals for our work on Western Screech-Owl in the interior are to: 
•	Support the B.C. Recovery Plan Population and Distribution Goal and Objectives
•	Be proactive in actions ahead of the federal recovery strategy updates including updates to critical habitat by focusing on high priority recovery actions from the B.C. Recovery Plan. 
•	Incorporate learning from the extensive work on Western Screech Owl coastal subspecies over the past 7 years. 

To support these goals, this year's project will:
•	Compile existing inventory and monitoring studies and associated occurrence records. Use this compilation to assess and complete occupancy analysis where possible. Finally, use compilation and occupancy analysis to inform a design for long-term monitoring strategy across the species range in the interior of BC. This compilation will be informed by Indigenous partners completing pilot studies under our Indigenous Funding Program agreements. 

Significant gaps in interior inventory and monitoring since 2012 limit our ability to identify priority habitats, assess connectivity, and locate nest trees. Updated inventory is therefore essential to support Objectives in the BC Recovery plan including associated recovery plan actions related to habitat protection, restoration, and stewardship. A long-term monitoring program is also needed to track occupancy, evaluate threats and measure effectiveness of management actions such as Wildlife Habitat Areas. Wildlife Habitat Area effectiveness monitoring supports Action 10 of the Together for Wildlife Strategy and aligns with the Kootenay Boundary region priorities for Western Screech Owl work.
CorrectT4WAction: The range wide monitoring strategy will consider existing and proposed WHAs and ensure they are incorporated so that future monitoring activities will contribute to Action 10 of the Together for Wildlife Strategy

Presence/absence of different species, as well as a "capture per unit effort" info about the abundance of the

selectProjectName.label: Monitoring the effects of stand thinning on bird, bat, and amphibian biodiversity in Omineca Sub Boreal Spruce habitat.
selectProjectName.value: Monitoring the effects of stand thinning on bird, bat, and amphibian biodiversity in Omineca Sub Boreal Spruce habitat.

General-FinalNotes: This project is in process, we have some data collected that is currently being analyzed; data collection is expected to continue over the winter and into 2026. Approval was given Nov 19, 2025 to move to EMC with $5,000 of expenses for the remaining project components, which include some equipment parts that were damaged in the field by wildlife, a software licence for data analysis, and a contract for expert review of recording data (to validate non-expert identifications/analysis). I needed to do some research to identify Canadian suppliers for the equipment, the best software and licensing terms for this particular use-case, and to identify the appropriate process and contract terms needed to engage a bioacoustician with applicable experience; these should be ready to enter the EMC process in early January 2026.
Status-StatusNotes: ARUs successfully detected bats in multiple locations that have no previous bat monitoring effort or data; currently working through acoustic (bird/frog) and ultrasonic (bat) collected between May and October of this year; units are still deployed in the field collecting data over the winter.

A history of rural, urban, and industrial development has had a profound impact on mule deer habitat and has adversly affected migration, winter survival and reproduction. BC established 400,000ha of Ungulate Winter Range (UWR) for mule deer in 2006 throughout the Okanagan trench.
